finding: The SNP rs525496 was identified as an expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) for several genes expressed in brain tissues, specifically TMSB15B, H2BFM, GLRA4, and LL0XNC01-116E7. It was found to be significantly associated with Parkinson Disease (PD) risk, showing an odds ratio (OR) of 0.60 in both the discovery and replication cohorts, indicating its role in higher PD resistance.

finding: The SNP rs28602900 was replicated in an independent cohort and associated with Parkinson Disease risk. Its initial finding was based on analyses that combined males and females. The consistent association further showed its relevance in understanding the genetic factors of PD, especially in non-European populations.

finding: Significant association with impulsivity was noted for rs5943997, which was linked to neurodevelopmental disorders, further supporting its novel association with the impulsivity phenotype.

finding: The SNP rs35318931, a missense variant linked to the SRPX gene (p.Ser413Phe), was pinpointed as a causal variant with considerable certainty (PP=87.3%). The SRPX protein is believed to play a role in extracellular matrix (ECM) function, emphasizing its potential involvement in hemorrhoidal pathology.

finding: The SNP rs4829762 located in GPC3 at Xq26.2 showcased relevance to PSA levels, contributing to the broader investigation of genetic determinants affecting PSA.

finding: The TLR7 rs179008 c.32T allele was a sex-specific protein expression quantitative trait locus (pQTL) that inhibited TLR7 protein expression and the TLR7-driven production of type 1 interferon (IFN-I) by plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) specifically in females, but not males. In HIV/ART women exhibiting the A/A or A/T genotypes, a lower frequency of IFN-α-producing pDCs was noted in those with the A/T genotype compared to those with A/A. This indicated that the rs179008 c.32A>T polymorphism controlled TLR7 expression and functionality in the context of HIV-1 infection and antiretroviral therapy.

finding: The variant rs184476359 in the AR gene was associated with PSA levels, showing a beta of -0.0590 (p=3.4e-10) in the multi-ancestry discovery phase and a beta of -0.0870 (p=6.3e-4) upon replication, indicating its role in prostate cancer.

finding: The variant rs12400785 near the CHRDL1 gene was significantly associated with a decreased risk of neonatal jaundice (OR = 0.80, p-value = 3.4 × 10-11, MAF = 36.6%). This finding underscored its independent role in the pathology of neonatal jaundice.

finding: The SNP rs12010166 was linked to enhanced knowledge regarding the cost-effectiveness of targeted multi-drug combination therapies in oncology. finding: The ACE2 rs2285666 polymorphism was associated with an elevated ACE2 expression up to 50%. This higher expression of ACE2 was implicated in increasing the risk for critical COVID-19, triggering vascular constriction, and resulting in worsening endothelial dysfunction, which may relate to symptoms experienced during Long-Haul COVID-19 (LHC) including dyspnea and fatigue.

title: Monocytes are the main source of STING-mediated IFN-α production

finding: The missense variant rs1050828 was identified as an association signal specific to the African ancestry (AFR) group, linked to higher reticulocyte counts and hematological parameters, revealing an important role in the context of G6PD deficiency and its protective effect against malaria.

finding: The SNP chrX:152767196:C:A was identified as significant only in females and related to the MAGEA6 gene, indicating sex-specific influences on LTL.

finding: The mutation rs913664484 was an extremely rare T>G transversion at the 5’ end of the first intron of the STAG2 gene, disrupting a splicing site and having a high impact on the gene product. This gene, associated with severe congenital and developmental defects in embryos and cancers, was studied in euploid miscarried embryos.
title: Prioritization of putatively detrimental variants in euploid miscarriages

finding: The SNP rs148312150, a loss-of-function coding variant in MAP3K15, was associated with protection against type 2 diabetes (T2D), showing a protective odds ratio of 0.824 (95% CI: [0.787, 0.864], p = 2.7e-17) among individuals at high polygenic risk. Additionally, carriers of this SNP demonstrated a significant median delay of 4.5 years in the age of T2D diagnosis. The association with high cholesterol also emerged, marked by a modest reduction in cholesterol and LDL/HDL ratios in MAP3K15 LoF carriers.
title: The Metabolic Role of MAP3K15: Genetic and Phenotypic Insights from the 23andMe Research Database and Genetics-Driven Recruitment

finding: The E35K polymorphism was found to have decreased binding affinity to the RBD of SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern (VOC), particularly the Beta, Delta, and Omicron RBDs. This decreased affinity was associated with a more protective phenotype against breakthrough infections.
title: Altered affinity to ACE2 and reduced Fc functional antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 RBD variants

finding: The K26R polymorphism demonstrated enhanced binding affinity to the ancestral RBD and VOCs Alpha and Delta, but showed slightly weaker binding to RBD-Beta. This finding indicated a potential increased susceptibility to breakthrough infections.
title: Altered affinity to ACE2 and reduced Fc functional antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 RBD variants

finding: The S19P polymorphism exhibited enhanced affinity to the ancestral RBD and all tested VOCs (Alpha, Beta, Delta, and Omicron). This enhancement in binding suggested a predisposition for individuals with this polymorphism to experience increased susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2.
title: Altered affinity to ACE2 and reduced Fc functional antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 RBD variants

finding: The rs28602900 SNP was located in a high gene density region near RPL10 and was associated with increased PD risk (OR = 1.10). This association was replicated in an independent dataset (OR = 1.16, P = 0.016) and was also shown to be a significant expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) regulating RPL10 expression across brain tissues. Additionally, it was related to reduced putamen volume, a biomarker for PD, with a significant association (β = -11.01, P = 0.011). These findings suggested a critical role of ribosomal proteins in PD pathogenesis.
title: Common X-chromosome variants are associated with Parkinson’s disease risk

finding: Variant rs782681704 was found in relation to fasting insulin (FI) levels. It is intronic to the BRCC3 gene and indicated probable regulatory activity, although it lacked clear evidence of being an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for BRCC3.
title: Investigating gene-diet interactions impacting the association between macronutrient intake and glycemic traits

finding: The rs2285666 polymorphism in the ACE2 gene was found to have a significant association with the spatial distribution of COVID-19 cases in India. title: Genetic diversity and spatiotemporal distribution of SARS-CoV-2 alpha variant in India

finding: The rs4364769 variant was identified as the index variant of the Xp22.32 locus in the r-XCI meta-analysis, showing a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.12, an odds ratio (OR) of 1.079, and a significant p-value of 2.55 x 10^-7. This signal was located over 300 kb from the closest protein coding gene, NLGN4X, indicating a potential but not direct genetic association with Alzheimer's Disease (AD).
title: X-Chromosome-wide association study for Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The index variant rs5933929 was associated with the FRMPD4 locus in the r-XCI meta-analysis. It presented a MAF of 0.38, an OR of 0.952, and a p-value of 1.98 x 10^-7. The variant resided in an intron within some transcripts of the FRMPD4 gene, suggesting a potential role in AD despite being located intronically.
title: X-Chromosome-wide association study for Alzheimer’s disease

finding: In the r-XCI meta-analysis, rs191195705 served as the index variant for the Xq25 signal, with a MAF of 0.11, an OR of 0.925, and a p-value of 7.09 x 10^-7. The variant was positioned over 500 kb from the nearest protein coding gene, GRIA3, and was suggested to primarily associate with AD risk in males.
title: X-Chromosome-wide association study for Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The variant rs5972406 was identified in the r-XCI meta-analysis as an index variant associated with an X-chromosome-wide significant locus. It had a MAF of 0.075, an OR of 1.143, and a p-value of 1.16 x 10^-6, being located within an intron of the dystrophin gene DMD, indicating a possible association with Alzheimer's Disease.
title: X-Chromosome-wide association study for Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The SNP rs2285666 was identified as a splice site variant associated with increased ACE2 expression. It was significantly more prevalent among SARS-CoV-2 positive patients (p = .015) and among hospitalized European patients compared to outpatients (p = .029). This variant potentially increased the risk of COVID-19 by elevating ACE2 levels and was previously noted as a risk factor for hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and coronary heart disease.

finding: The eQTL rs12006793 was shown to decrease ACE2 expression and was more prevalent in controls, suggesting it potentially reduced the risk of COVID-19. It had the largest effect size (d = 0.91) among the eQTLs studied and was statistically different in prevalence among ethnic groups (p < 0.001). This variant also remained significant in comparisons between hospitalized and non-hospitalized SARS-CoV-2 positive patients.
title: SARS-CoV-2 susceptibility and ACE2 gene variations within diverse ethnic backgrounds

finding: The rare G6PD variant rs76723693 had effects on HbA1c that were noted to be larger than the commonly observed G202A variant. This finding indicated that carriers of rs76723693 had significantly lower HbA1c levels, suggesting it impacted glycemic status in individuals with African genetic ancestry.
title: Non-glycemic genetic effects on HbA1c and clinical glycemic status in African ancestry: VA Million Veteran Program

finding: The SNP rs1379871 was highlighted as a likely causal variant in the DMD locus with a high posterior probability, contributing significant findings for BMI among diverse populations.
title: WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCING ANALYSIS OF BODY MASS INDEX IDENTIFIES NOVEL AFRICAN ANCESTRY-SPECIFIC RISK ALLELE

finding: This SNP was identified as an X-chromosomal locus associated with omega-3% in males. The lead variant rs147828433 was linked to the gene ACOT9, suggesting a regulatory role in fatty acid and amino acid metabolism.
title: Genome-wide association studies and multi-omics integrative analysis reveal novel loci and their molecular mechanisms for circulating polyunsaturated, monounsaturated, and saturated fatty acids

finding: The SNP rs1044165 showed a significant association with CHD but only in the heterozygous inheritance model (AG vs GG+AA; OR = 0.3442; P = 0.0276), suggesting a specific role in CHD risk.
title: The potential impact of microRNA-related functional polymorphisms in the pathogenesis of coronary heart disease

finding: SNP rs12012736 was one of the significant COJO SNPs related to C4 protein concentration and was located on chromosome X, potentially influencing sex differences in autoimmune disorder risks.
title: The genetic and phenotypic correlates of neonatal Complement Component 3 and 4 protein concentrations with a focus on psychiatric and autoimmune disorders

finding: Associated with varicose veins and linked to <italic>POF1B</italic>.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: The rs4830976 variant was found to be positively associated with COVID-19 hospitalization, indicating that its correlation with ACE2 expression may contribute to increased risk.
title: Actionable druggable genome-wide Mendelian randomization identifies repurposing opportunities for COVID-19

finding: The SNP rs140104197, a protein-truncating variant (Arg1122*), was associated with a significantly decreased risk of both type 1 diabetes (T1DM) with an odds ratio (OR) of 0.58 and type 2 diabetes (T2DM) with an OR of 0.82 in the FinnGen cohort. This SNP's finding was previously identified in the UK Biobank study with rare variants in MAP3K15 suggesting protective effects against diabetes.
title: Human genetic evidence supports MAP3K15 inhibition as a therapeutic strategy for diabetes

finding: This SNP, located on chromosome X, was associated with increased testosterone across all ancestry groups and was significantly linked to lower odds of diabetes specifically in the African ancestry group.
title: Discovery of Novel Trans-Ancestry and Ancestry-Specific Gene Loci for Total Testosterone in a Multi-Ancestral Analysis of Men in the Million Veteran Program

finding: This African-specific ancestry variant on chromosome X was associated with lower testosterone levels and higher odds of chronic kidney disease and renal failure, as well as being linked to diabetes and renal function metrics.
title: Discovery of Novel Trans-Ancestry and Ancestry-Specific Gene Loci for Total Testosterone in a Multi-Ancestral Analysis of Men in the Million Veteran Program

finding: This TKTL1 variant on chromosome X was uniquely associated with hereditary hemolytic anemias in the Hispanic ancestry group, which provided insight into the genetic regulation of anemia related to testosterone.
title: Discovery of Novel Trans-Ancestry and Ancestry-Specific Gene Loci for Total Testosterone in a Multi-Ancestral Analysis of Men in the Million Veteran Program

finding: The SNP rs9697983, located in the gene GLUD2, was identified as the candidate causal SNP for the pathways associated with electronic transport and metabolism. This finding was part of a broader analysis that indicated its significance in the context of blood coagulation pathways associated with age-related macular degeneration (AMD), reinforcing previous literature connections.
title: Identifying X-Chromosome Variants Associated with Age-Related Macular Degeneration

finding: The rs6610096 SNP was identified in the prostate associated gene PAGE4, showing significant association in males, females, and combined analyses. This SNP's association related to immune function and may contribute to TB susceptibility.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: The rs7888114 SNP located in the FRMPD4 gene was significant in the male and combined analyses. This gene has potential implications for TB susceptibility, having been previously identified in an interaction analysis.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: The rs4465088 SNP was located downstream of the ACTRT1 gene, associated with females showing an OR of 4.73 and was additionally significant in the combined analysis. This variant suggested escape from X chromosome inactivation, implying overexpression in females.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: The rs2428212 SNP was significant in females within the African cohort, revealing an OR of 2.03. It is located in the UPF3B gene, which is involved in nonsense-mediated mRNA decay, suggesting a potential influence on TB through RNA regulation.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: The rs2563800 SNP was associated in males and combined analysis located in LOC105373293, a non-coding RNA. Its association with TB susceptibility requires further investigation for functional relevance.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: The rs5975736 SNP was identified in the Bombesin Receptor Subtype 3 gene within the combined analysis, suggesting a role in TB susceptibility connected to its influence on energy homeostasis.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: The lead SNP rs12687599 was associated with a region containing the genes ASB9 and ASB11 in the Male-XWAS analysis. It demonstrated a highly significant p-value of 3.57×10−7, revealing a potential link between sex hormone pathways and Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) particularly in males.
title: Chromosome X-Wide Common Variant Association Study (XWAS) in Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: This SNP was identified in the long non-coding RNA region encompassing DDX53/PTCHD1-AS with a significant p-value of 9.47×10−6, indicating its association with ASD through the involvement of regulatory pathways linked to the disorder.
title: Chromosome X-Wide Common Variant Association Study (XWAS) in Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: Detected in the Both-XWAS analysis, this variant demonstrated consistent significant p-values across all cohort tests, indicating its strong association with ASD through its relationship with the PDHA1 gene.
title: Chromosome X-Wide Common Variant Association Study (XWAS) in Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: The SNP rs12010150 was significantly associated with elevated polygenic risk scores (PRSs) for autoimmune-related diseases, particularly in exceptional responders (ERs) to cancer treatment. This finding indicated that ERs had a higher risk score for diseases such as type 1 diabetes (T1D) and hypothyroidism, suggesting a potential link between these autoimmune disorders and better cancer treatment responses.
title: Polygenic risk scores for autoimmune related diseases are significantly different and skewed in cancer exceptional responders

finding: The SNP rs1190734 showed a genome-wide significant association with the 'heavy-smoker' phenotype in American ancestry (OR=0.83; CI=0.79-0.88; P=1.2e-11), while demonstrating only a nominal association in European ancestry. It indicated potential differential effects of this locus on smoking behaviors across different populations.
title: Rare coding variants in CHRNB2 reduce the likelihood of smoking

finding: The missense variant rs1050828 in the G6PD gene was significantly associated with several phenotypes primarily in the African ancestry group, including glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c). The p-value for the association was extremely low (1.1 x 10^-299), indicating a robust association, while its frequency in AFR was markedly higher than in EUR.
title: Pan-UK Biobank GWAS improves discovery, analysis of genetic architecture, and resolution into ancestry-enriched effects

finding: The study found that the SNP rs3810682 (g.50910775C>G) in the promoter region of the BMP15 gene was present in three cases, with one case exhibiting a homozygous change and two cases showing a heterozygous change. The prevalence of this SNP was reported as 10.7% in POF cases compared to 3.3% in healthy controls, suggesting a potential association with Premature Ovarian Failure (POF). Although the results indicated a higher prevalence in cases, the statistical significance was not achieved (P-value = 0.344), likely due to the small sample size, but this may indicate a trend towards an association. Furthermore, the presence of both primary and secondary amenorrhea in affected individuals suggested that these SNPs might be linked to ovarian dysfunction, which is characteristic of POF.
title: Cytogenetic & Molecular analysis in Premature Ovarian Failure

finding: The lead variant rs778479352 exhibited a strong association with atrial fibrillation with an odds ratio of 2.00. It was located in an intron of FGF13, which is implicated in cardiac sodium channel function, indicating its role in conduction disturbances relevant to atrial fibrillation.
title: Trans-ancestry genome-wide analysis of atrial fibrillation provides new insights into disease biology and enables polygenic prediction of cardioembolic risk

finding: The alternative allele in homozygosis for rs228406, which maps to the DMD gene, was associated with the noFAST phenotype. This finding was significant in distinguishing patients with more severe renal progression from those without such symptoms.
title: IDENTIFICATION OF MODIFIER GENE VARIANTS OVERREPRESENTED IN FAMILIAL HYPOMAGNESEMIA WITH HYPERCALCIURIA AND NEPHROCALCINOSIS PATIENTS WITH A MORE AGGRESSIVE RENAL PHENOTYPE

finding: The study reported that roughly 11% of African-Americans carry the rs1050828 variant, which is known to shorten the mean erythrocyte lifespan. This variant may potentially lead to approximately 0.65 million African-American individuals being undiagnosed for type 2 diabetes (T2D), highlighting its significant impact on T2D diagnosis based on HbA1C measurements.
title: A combined polygenic score of 21,293 rare and 22 common variants significantly improves diabetes diagnosis based on hemoglobin A1C levels

finding: The variant rs6612886 showed significant allelic shift in mLOX cases, with findings pointing to a propensity for one allele over another, critical for understanding X-linked mechanisms.
title: Population analyses of mosaic X chromosome loss identify genetic drivers and widespread signatures of cellular selection

finding: The SNP rs626840, located in EFNB1, was found to be associated with retinal thickness. Mutations in EFNB1 are linked to craniofrontonasal syndrome, which includes various ophthalmologic abnormalities.
title: Multi-omic spatial effects on high-resolution AI-derived retinal thickness

finding: This intronic variant in SHROOM2 was linked to retinal thickness, with mutations causing pigmentation issues in the retinal pigment epithelium.
title: Multi-omic spatial effects on high-resolution AI-derived retinal thickness

finding: The MAOA polymorphism (rs1137070), where a C allele replaces a T, indicated that higher MAOA activity could be linked to increased catalyzation of neurotransmitters like serotonin and norepinephrine. While a meta-analysis suggested that the T variant was associated with major depression in non-pregnant populations, interactions with other genes indicated a potential role in perinatal depression, particularly under certain circumstances.
title: A sum of its parts: A systematic review evaluating biopsychosocial and behavioral determinants of perinatal depression

finding: The SNP rs12010034 was linked to a study concerning Pressurized Intraperitoneal Aerosol Chemotherapy (PIPAC) which aimed to overcome drug resistance using physical principles. This study indicated that certain genetic factors could play a role in the efficacy of PIPAC treatments.
title: Performance of different nebulizers in clinical use for Pressurized Intraperitoneal Aerosol Chemotherapy (PIPAC)

finding: The rs17332232 SNP was associated with the IL1RAPL2 locus, identified through X chromosome analysis in the context of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). This SNP was previously overlooked in ALS genomics and encodes a protein that is specific to the central nervous system. Its relevance was underscored by its association with the interactome of interleukin-2, a cytokine under clinical investigation for its neuroprotective properties in ALS. The findings suggested that stratifying trial data by the rs17332232 genotype could potentially highlight pharmacogenomic factors contributing to therapeutic benefits observed in clinical trials.
title: Sex-specific risk loci and modified MEF2C expression in ALS

finding: The SNP rs145400922 was found to be associated with cardioembolic stroke at the genome-wide significance level in analyses restricted to Black participants, according to the findings from the TOPMed analysis.
title: Whole Exome Sequencing Analyses Support a Role of Vitamin D Metabolism in Ischemic Stroke

finding: The rs5987128 splice donor pLoF variant was associated with reduced blood pressure (BP). This variant might have escaped detection in previous GWAS due to its location on the X-chromosome, which was often excluded from large GWAS efforts. The effect of this variant on BP was novel.
title: Association analyses of predicted loss-of-function variants prioritized 15 genes as blood pressure regulators

finding: Common variant in F9 associated with VTE, adding to the previously reported variants related to the disorder.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS for venous thromboembolism identifies novel loci followed by experimental validation in zebrafish

finding: An upstream variant near BCOR identified in the study that associated with VTE, showcasing a relevant linkage to genetic mechanisms underlying the condition.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS for venous thromboembolism identifies novel loci followed by experimental validation in zebrafish

finding: This SNP, located in FUNDC2, was previously nominally associated with VTE and linked to platelet survival mechanisms.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS for venous thromboembolism identifies novel loci followed by experimental validation in zebrafish

finding: The variant rs190509934 was identified as a rare variant associated with a lower risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection, showing an odds ratio of 0.60 (P=4.5x10^-13) and located near the ACE2 gene. It was associated with a significant reduction in ACE2 expression by 0.87 standard deviation units, suggesting its role in modulating COVID-19 risk.
title: Genome-wide analysis in 756,646 individuals provides first genetic evidence that ACE2 expression influences COVID-19 risk and yields genetic risk scores predictive of severe disease

finding: This SNP on Xp21.2 had a z of 5.77 and was linked to IL1RAPL1, known for its implications in intellectual disability and autism.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: Identified on Xp11.23, this SNP (z=5.80), was associated with upregulation in glioblastoma-related genes.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: On Xq11.2, this SNP had a z-score of 6.61 and was related to MTMR8, suggesting its role in actin filament regulation and patterns of asymmetry.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: The SNP rs140385304 was identified as being located 153kb centromeric to the Cas9 cut site in an embryo containing a chromosome X fragment. It was associated with significant genomic loss, including breakage at the centromere resulting in the loss of more than 1 Mb, exemplifying the potential impact of DNA double-strand breaks in CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing.
title: DNA Double Strand Breaks cause chromosome loss through sister chromatid tethering in human embryos

finding: The SNP rs56355347 was detected at 41bp telomeric of the Cas9 cut site in a male embryo. It exhibited a detectable signal and indicated that reciprocal whole and segmental chromosome changes occurred across all 8 analyzed cells, showcasing the preservation of the cut site through three cell divisions and highlighting the chromosomal instability associated with DSBs.
title: DNA Double Strand Breaks cause chromosome loss through sister chromatid tethering in human embryos

finding: The rs6641874 variant was identified as the top variant associated with PRKX gene expression in T cells and was a significant eQTL signal in the analysis of lymphocyte counts. The data indicated that this SNP showed larger effect sizes in females compared to males, suggesting a differential impact on lymphocyte counts likely related to X chromosome inactivation escape.
title: Quantification of the escape from X chromosome inactivation with the million cell-scale human single-cell omics datasets reveals heterogeneity of escape across cell types and tissues

finding: The rs6641601 variant was the top variant associated with PRKX gene expression in monocytes. Similar to rs6641874, it demonstrated a female bias in effect sizes for lymphocyte counts, supporting the hypothesis of sex differences in gene expression influenced by genetic factors associated with X chromosome inactivation escape.
title: Quantification of the escape from X chromosome inactivation with the million cell-scale human single-cell omics datasets reveals heterogeneity of escape across cell types and tissues

finding: The G>C substitution (SNP rs138166791) in the penultimate position of pre-miR-890 significantly lowered the cleavage efficiency by DROSHA. This, in turn, decreased the levels of mature miR-890-5p and miR-890-3p, demonstrating its potential impact on miRNA biogenesis and target recognition.
title: Somatic mutations in miRNA genes in lung cancer – potential functional consequences of non-coding sequence variants

finding: The SNP rs11091220 was positively associated with various phenotypes related to the expression of p21 (Cip1/Waf1/CDKN1A), which is relevant for cell differentiation and cancer therapy. The context highlighted the role of this gene in processes such as cell cycle arrest and potential links to metabolic functions during hibernation.
title: The meadow jumping mouse genome and transcriptome suggest mechanisms of hibernation

finding: The SNP rs1978124 was found to exhibit differential frequency distribution across global populations, particularly differentiating between sub-population groups such as AFR, AMR, and SAS, which indicated a diverse genetic background. It was located in the intron 1 region of the ACE2 gene and was associated with enhancer activity that may influence ACE2 gene expression linked to SARS-CoV-2 entry in host cells.
title: ACE2 Homo-dimerization, Human Genomic variants and Interaction of Host Proteins Explain High Population Specific Differences in Outcomes of COVID19

finding: SNP rs2106809 also displayed differential frequency distribution similar to rs1978124 among global populations, indicating it could have a significant impact on population-specific responses to SARS-CoV-2. This SNP was likewise situated in the ACE2 gene's intronic region and was associated with enhancer histone marks speculated to regulate ACE2 expression.
title: ACE2 Homo-dimerization, Human Genomic variants and Interaction of Host Proteins Explain High Population Specific Differences in Outcomes of COVID19

finding: HTR2C rs1414334 C/C genotype individuals experienced significant weight gain during olanzapine treatment compared to T allele carriers. This finding supports the link between this polymorphism and susceptibility to weight gain from antipsychotics.
title: Metabolic effects of aripiprazole and olanzapine multiple-dose treatment in healthy volunteers. Association with pharmacogenetics

finding: The rs142984500 ACE2 polymorphism was associated with increased RBD-ACE2 binding affinity. This SNP, common among Europeans, was predicted to increase genetic susceptibility to COVID-19 when interacting with the SARS-CoV-2 virus.
title: Differences between Omicron SARS-CoV-2 RBD and other variants in their ability to interact with cell receptors and monoclonal antibodies

finding: The rs4646116 SNP was found to be related to increased binding affinity for the RBD of SARS-CoV-2, indicating a potential genetic factor impacting susceptibility to the virus.
title: Differences between Omicron SARS-CoV-2 RBD and other variants in their ability to interact with cell receptors and monoclonal antibodies

finding: The ACE2 rs2285666 polymorphism was associated with an increased risk of infection and fatality in COVID-19 cases, highlighting its relevance as a genetic factor affecting the severity of the disease.
title: Differences between Omicron SARS-CoV-2 RBD and other variants in their ability to interact with cell receptors and monoclonal antibodies

finding: The rs759579097 variant was identified as protective, as it was associated with decreased RBD-ACE2 binding affinity, suggesting that carriers of this polymorphism might exhibit lower susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: Differences between Omicron SARS-CoV-2 RBD and other variants in their ability to interact with cell receptors and monoclonal antibodies

finding: The K31R polymorphism (rs758278442) was associated with reduced binding affinity between RBD and ACE2, indicating that individuals carrying this variant may be less susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: Differences between Omicron SARS-CoV-2 RBD and other variants in their ability to interact with cell receptors and monoclonal antibodies

finding: This SNP (E37K, rs146676783) demonstrated a decrease in RBD-ACE2 binding affinity, implying that individuals with this polymorphism could exhibit lower susceptibility to COVID-19 infection.
title: Differences between Omicron SARS-CoV-2 RBD and other variants in their ability to interact with cell receptors and monoclonal antibodies

finding: The SNP rs12092652 was associated with the activation of NRF2 and the oxidative stress response specifically in immune-regulatory cancer-associated fibroblasts and a unique subset of cancer associated pericytes across various carcinoma types. This finding highlighted its involvement in the tumor microenvironment, especially in relation to pathways affecting survival in cancer.
title: Mapping the tumor stress network reveals dynamic shifts in the stromal oxidative stress response

finding: The polymorphism rs3761548 in FoxP3 was identified to predict autoimmune disease susceptibility, which could have relevance in autoimmune responses associated with colorectal conditions.
title: Identification of hub genes and key pathways in pediatric Crohn’s disease using next generation sequencing and bioinformatics analysis

finding: The common G6PD variant rs1050828 was associated with NADPH generation, linking it to the oxidative stress response in RBCs and potentially influencing hemolytic outcomes.
title: Ferroptosis regulates hemolysis in stored murine and human red blood cells

finding: For rs185941206, HWE was rejected as females were found to be monomorphic, while males exhibited all three alleles. This indicated a violation of Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium due to sex-specific allele distributions.
title: A network algorithm for the X chromosomal exact test for Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium with multiple alleles

finding: HWE was rejected for rs112679846 since males were monomorphic with a large number of alternate alleles in females, highlighting a disparity in allele frequencies between sexes.
title: A network algorithm for the X chromosomal exact test for Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium with multiple alleles

finding: The SNP rs6318 (Cys23Ser or 68G>C) was found to be involved in the dimerization of 5-HT2A and 5-HT2C receptors. This SNP has been implicated in a variety of neuropsychiatric diseases, including eating and anxiety disorders, obesity, depression, bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, and cocaine use disorder, indicating its significance in behavioral processes and mental health.
title: Protein Co-Evolution Strategies Detect Predicted Functional Interaction Between the Serotonin 5-HT2A and 5-HT2C Receptors

finding: The SNP rs4549940 showed a positive association with uric acid levels, confirming its previously reported significance in the UK biobank.
title: Understanding Complex Trait Susceptibilities and Ethnical Diversity in a Sample of 4,145 Russians Through Analysis of Clinical and Genetic Data

finding: At locus IRAK1, rs1059702 was identified as an allelic enhancer variant, with the risk allele influencing allelic enhancer activity.
title: Genome-wide discovery of SLE genetic risk variant allelic enhancer activity

finding: The variant rs3027878, associated with HCFC1, was implicated as an allelic enhancer variant affecting transcriptional activity.
title: Genome-wide discovery of SLE genetic risk variant allelic enhancer activity

finding: The variant was associated with lower basophil percentages among individuals carrying coding variants in the ACE2 gene. This finding suggested a weak protective effect of these coding variants against hypertension, which aligns with the gene's known function related to blood pressure regulation.
title: Revealing variants in SARS-CoV-2 interaction domain of ACE2 and loss of function intolerance through analysis of >200,000 exomes

finding: The low-frequency intronic variant rs183546232 in ACE2 (MAF 1%) was nominally associated with eosinophilic esophagitis in an independent dataset, indicating a predisposition for individuals with coding variants in ACE2 to develop gastro-esophageal reflux disease with oesophagitis.
title: Revealing variants in SARS-CoV-2 interaction domain of ACE2 and loss of function intolerance through analysis of >200,000 exomes

finding: The variant chrX:15600835:T:C (p.K26R) was noted for being the most common among variants that interact with SARS-CoV-2, with an allele frequency of ~0.5% across several populations. It changed the amino acid directly adjacent to a SARS-CoV-2 interacting site but was not predicted to be damaging.
title: Revealing variants in SARS-CoV-2 interaction domain of ACE2 and loss of function intolerance through analysis of >200,000 exomes

finding: The variant chrX:15600857:A:G (p.S19P) was recognized as a damaging variant that directly affects a SARS-CoV-2 interacting amino acid and exhibited a rare allele frequency of 0.1-0.2% in populations with African ancestry, suggesting potential implications for susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: Revealing variants in SARS-CoV-2 interaction domain of ACE2 and loss of function intolerance through analysis of >200,000 exomes

finding: The SNP rs62621675, represented as [C>G], was analyzed using the AsCRISPR tool. The analysis yielded 24 discriminating sgRNAs when combining the original Cas9 variants, including notable subtypes such as SpCas9-V(R)QR and SaCas9-KKH. Additionally, novel PAM sequences were created by this SNP, further facilitating allele-specific targeting.
title: AsCRISPR: a web server for allele-specific sgRNA design in precision medicine

finding: The SNP rs2272737 showed a strong association with 96 imaging-derived phenotypes (IDPs), specifically related to the properties of white matter tracts in the cerebrum. It also served as an eQTL for the gene FAM58A, which is implicated in STAR, a rare X-linked developmental disorder.
title: Enhanced Brain Imaging Genetics in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs1894299 was associated with the same cluster as rs2272737 and was previously noted in a GWAS of Type 2 diabetes. It is located in an intron of the DUSP9 gene, which codes for a phosphatase involved in protecting against insulin resistance, and had links to dietary habits of UK Biobank participants.
title: Enhanced Brain Imaging Genetics in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs644138 was associated with 28 local brain volume IDPs, primarily in the occipital lobe. It is situated in a pseudoautosomal region within the SPRY3 gene, which is linked to various neurodevelopmental disorders.
title: Enhanced Brain Imaging Genetics in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs12843772 was associated with the volume of grey matter regions in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and the lateral parietal cortex. It is located near the ZIC3 gene, which is crucial for body pattern formation, and is associated with neural developmental disorders.
title: Enhanced Brain Imaging Genetics in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs1403543 was associated with cystic fibrosis severity through a genome-wide association study (GWAS), with a statistically significant p-value of 2e-6. This variant was the only one positively linked to any phenotype in the context of the study.
title: Cell type-specific expression of angiotensin receptors in the human lung with implications for health, aging, and chronic disease

finding: This SNP was previously linked to age of first sexual intercourse and educational attainment, indicating a relationship with SES.
title: Polygenic predictions of occupational status GWAS elucidate genetic and environmental interplay for intergenerational status transmission, careers, and health

finding: The SNP rs7886851-A was significantly associated with the transition from first cocaine use to cocaine use disorder (CUD), showing a p value of 0.002 in the analysis.
title: USP7/Maged1-Mediated H2A Monoubiquitination in the Paraventricular Thalamus: An Epigenetic Mechanism Involved in Cocaine Use Disorder

finding: Similar to rs7886851, the SNP rs6614508-A was also significantly associated with the transition from first cocaine use to CUD, with a p value of 0.002.
title: USP7/Maged1-Mediated H2A Monoubiquitination in the Paraventricular Thalamus: An Epigenetic Mechanism Involved in Cocaine Use Disorder

finding: The SNP rs142516556, located near the G6PD gene, showed a strong association with pyruvate levels, and this association remained consistent despite various analysis adjustments, underscoring its influence on RBC metabolomics.
title: Genome-wide metabolite quantitative trait loci analysis (mQTL) in red blood cells from volunteer blood donors

finding: The SNP rs12010115 was associated with the retrieval of vegetation fractions from multispectral sensors. It played a role in distinguishing between photosynthetic and non-photosynthetic vegetation, contributing to enhanced accuracy in vegetation classification and analysis.
title: SegVeg: Segmenting RGB images into green and senescent vegetation by combining deep and shallow methods

finding: The SNP rs387906727 was associated with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). The study found that mutations in the RPL10 gene, linked to this SNP, were predicted to be deleterious. This finding indicated that altered interactions between the mutated RPL10 protein and its interacting partners could negatively affect neuronal pathways, which are commonly disrupted in ASD.
title: In silico analysis of the altered protein structure and functions caused by existing synaptic gene mutations in Indian population having neurological disorders

finding: The SNP rs3827440, identified as a nonsynonymous single nucleotide polymorphism within the GPR174 gene located on the X chromosome, was found to be associated with Graves' disease in the Polish Caucasian population. This association highlighted its potential role in autoimmune disease mechanisms.
title: Identification of ABHD6 as a regulator of lysophosphatidylserines in the mammalian liver and kidneys

finding: The Asn-Asp missense variant rs1050829 in G6PD was associated with G6PD deficiency, showing a high observed value of 68.8, which placed it among the top 0.5% of all variants. This finding linked it to significant adaptive evolution due to selective pressure from malaria.
title: Three hallmarks of malaria-induced selection in human genomes

finding: The Ala-Val missense variant rs1340989 in ABCB7 was located at the peak of a 3 Mb region on the X chromosome. It was part of a genomic signal that included over 100 variants showing values above 200, reflecting strong selective pressure likely related to malaria resistance.
title: Three hallmarks of malaria-induced selection in human genomes

finding: The SNP rs12010173 was identified as a positive finding in the context of tree-to-tree variations in cone production in Stone Pine (Pinus pinea L.), as noted in the study by Schneider et al. (2020). This SNP was statistically associated with variations in functional traits that influence resource acquisition, which in turn affected reproductive outputs in the analyzed species. The study highlighted how specific genetic variations can quantify key components impacting the life-history strategies of long-lived plant species.
title: An integrative trait-based framework to infer resource budgets and life-histories of long-lived plants

finding: The study confirmed that the ACE2 rs2074192 TT genotype resulted in increased ACE2 mRNA and protein expression in placental organoids. This increase was accompanied by altered ACE2:ACE ratios, suggesting a direct role in placental development and implications for complications like small-for-gestational-age (SGA) outcomes.
title: Genetically edited human placental organoids cast new light on the role of ACE2 in placental development

finding: The SNP rs132630284 was identified with a pathogenic mutation D168N in the myelin proteolipid protein (P60201-2). This was supported by 5 confident PSMs associated with the variant peptide TSASIGSLCANAR.
title: Quality control of variant peptides identified through proteogenomics- catching the (un)usual suspects

finding: The noncoding variant rs4646118 was found in approximately 9% of individuals of African descent. It was noted for its potential role in regulating transcriptional expression of the ACE2 gene, suggesting it could contribute to increased susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection in at-risk populations, particularly African males.
title: SARS-CoV2 (COVID-19) Structural/Evolution Dynamicome: Insights into functional evolution and human genomics

finding: Similarly, the noncoding variant rs143185769 was also present in about 9% of African descent individuals. Its potential to alter ACE2 gene expression positioned it as a significant factor that might increase vulnerability to SARS-CoV-2, especially in higher-risk groups such as African and male populations.
title: SARS-CoV2 (COVID-19) Structural/Evolution Dynamicome: Insights into functional evolution and human genomics

finding: The ACE2 variant H378R (rs142984500) was observed in 0.019% of European non-Finnish individuals. Identified as one of the critical residues for zinc binding that drives the enzyme's function, this missense variant's hemizygous nature in six males suggests its importance in protein function, and it had not been previously published.
title: SARS-CoV2 (COVID-19) Structural/Evolution Dynamicome: Insights into functional evolution and human genomics

finding: The SNP rs5935988 was assigned to the gene COBLL1, associated with body fat distribution and insulin signaling, highlighting its importance in obesity-related genetic studies.
title: Identifying latent genetic interactions in genome-wide association studies using multiple traits

finding: The SNP rs12010103 had been linked to aging and epigenetic changes in studies of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML). The research indicated that this polymorphism could influence the development of AML in relation to age-related changes in hematopoiesis. This finding underscored the importance of genetic factors in understanding hematological disorders as they relate to aging.
title: Rat Leukocyte Population Dynamics Predicts a Window for Intervention in Aging

finding: The SNP rs73635825 caused the S19P amino acid variant, which was identified as the most frequent variant affecting the ACE2/Spike binding interface, with a frequency of 0.06% in the population. It showed a significant GBPM score supporting its relevance in the interaction with the viral Spike protein.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs143936283, associated with the E329G variant, was a rare allele in the population, with a frequency of 0.0066% in the European non-Finnish Asian population. Its location in the ACE2/Spike binding interface suggested potential relevance, though its overall frequency limited its impact on the broader population.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The rs766996587 SNP represented the M82I variant, noted as a very rare allele present in 0.0066% of the African population. It was situated at a location potentially affecting the ACE2/Spike interaction, although its rarity diminished its population-level impact.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: SNP rs146676783 was associated with the E37K variant, more frequently found in the Finnish population (0.03%). It was positioned in the binding interface, indicating that it could influence the interaction between ACE2 and Spike, but lacked extensive clinical significance.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs370610075 was tied to the G352V variant, found more frequently in the European non-Finnish population (0.007%). It was also found at the ACE2/Spike binding interface, which hinted it may play a role in binding dynamics, yet it remained without reported clinical significance.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The rs28933690 SNP, which results in the C294R amino acid change, was found to be pathogenic. This conclusion was corroborated by clinical results obtained from the dbSNPs/NCBI database, indicating that it had a detrimental effect on the XK protein structure and function.
title: Unmasking of novel mutations within XK gene that could be used as Diagnostic Markers to Predict McLeod syndrome: Using in silico analysis

finding: The rs145996031 SNP, causing the Y370D change, was identified as novel and was labeled as damaging. It was further noted that this SNP might be linked to L1 syndrome, suggesting significant implications for both XK functionality and potential clinical relevance.
title: Unmasking of novel mutations within XK gene that could be used as Diagnostic Markers to Predict McLeod syndrome: Using in silico analysis

finding: In males, the functional connectivity between the precuneus cluster and the right middle temporal gyrus significantly correlated with rs1465108 (r = -0.22, P = 0.030), suggesting a relationship between this SNP and ADHD-associated connectivity alterations.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: In males, the connectivity between the precuneus cluster and the right middle temporal gyrus also showed a significant correlation with rs5906883 (r = -0.21, P = 0.037), indicating its involvement in ADHD-related brain function disruptions.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The functional connectivity between the precuneus cluster and the right middle temporal gyrus revealed a significant association with rs6323 (r = -0.22, P = 0.027) in males, linking this SNP to ADHD's neurofunctional profile.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: For males, there was a significant correlation between the functional connectivity from precuneus to right middle temporal gyrus and rs5905859 (r = 0.23, P = 0.023), highlighting its potential role in ADHD mechanisms.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: In females, rs1799836 showed a significant correlation (r = 0.28, P = 0.005) between the left middle temporal cluster and the right inferior temporal gyrus, establishing a connection with ADHD-related functional connectivity.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: Female participants demonstrated a significant correlation for rs10521432 (r = 0.20, P = 0.045) between the left middle temporal cluster and the dorsolateral aspect of the left superior frontal gyrus, indicating its relevance to ADHD.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: Both in males (r = -0.22, P = 0.027) with left middle temporal gyrus connectivity and in females (r = 0.36, P = 0.041) with right superior parietal gyrus, rs2239449 linked to functional connectivity alterations related to ADHD.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: In males, rs2283729 (r = -0.25, P = 0.010) correlated with the left middle temporal gyrus and in females, (r = 0.36, P = 0.041) it was associated with changes in connectivity with superior parietal gyrus, demonstrating its significance in ADHD.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: For males, significant correlations were found for rs6651806 (r = 0.25, P = 0.010 and r = 0.30, P = 0.002 with the left middle temporal gyrus), while in females, correlations included (r = -0.36, P = 0.041) with spatial changes involving left middle temporal cluster.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: In males, rs2283727 (r = 0.27, P = 0.007) was significantly correlated with functional connectivity changes between the precuneus cluster and various cortical regions. In females, it also correlated (r = 0.39, P = 0.025) marking its role in ADHD.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The SNP rs3027441 correlated significantly in males (r = 0.22, P = 0.027) and in females (r = -0.20, P = 0.043) with connections in the left middle temporal cluster, highlighting its relevance in ADHD connectivity.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: In males, significant correlation for rs5952671 (r = -0.22, P = 0.027) was found concerning middle temporal gyrus connectivity. In females, this SNP demonstrated correlations (r = -0.39, P = 0.025), establishing a significant relationship with ADHD.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The TIMP-1 gene polymorphism rs6609533 was also found to be related to susceptibility to type 2 diabetes, suggesting a multifactorial genetic basis for the disorder.
title: Screening key genes and signaling pathways in COVID-19 infection and its associated complications by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP rs12010065 was identified in the context of land cover classification within complex agroecosystems of the Galapagos Islands. It served as an original finding related to the study of how invasive species, specifically guava, influence the demographic decline of native species like guayabillo. This SNP was significant in understanding the genetic aspects associated with the ecological dynamics impacting the native populations.
title: Local exclusion and regional decline of an endemic Galápagos tree species (Psidium galapageium) by an invasive relative (P. guajava)

finding: The study identified that rs1399200 regulated VPS13C, which is associated with endoplasmic reticulum functions. This finding contributes to understanding how genetic variants can influence gene regulation in the context of SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: It was found that rs6632680 interacted with PHKA2, which is involved in phosphorylase kinase regulation. This association indicated potential trans-regulatory mechanisms at work within the ACE2 locus, further emphasizing its role in inflammatory responses relevant to lung conditions.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: The SNP rs714205 was mentioned as having significant minor allele frequency biases across different populations, which indicated selective pressures that may impact regulation of the PIR gene, particularly in the context of hypertension and inflammatory responses.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: This SNP was linked to regulatory elements in CA5B, showing changes in transcription factor binding sites. Prior associations suggested roles in hypertension and cardiovascular conditions, which are relevant to ACE2's function and SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: The variant rs2285666 was noted for altering transcription factor binding sites and exhibiting significant selection towards the reference allele across populations. It was associated with implications for hypertension and inflammatory responses, underscoring its importance in the ACE2 regulatory context.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: This SNP demonstrated a notable impact on transcription factors and was reported to have allele-specific effects in hypertension and cardiovascular disease. It emphasized the relationship between genetic variation and the regulatory environment surrounding ACE2.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: The study highlighted rs6629111's involvement in regulating CA5B expression, suggesting its potential role in respiratory and inflammatory processes. This finding aligned with the ongoing exploration of ACE2's regulatory mechanisms.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: While specific details weren't elaborated, rs1514280 was included among regulatory sites identified within ACE2, indicating its possible involvement in modulating ACE2 expression and related inflammatory responses.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: This SNP was similarly classified within the regulatory network impacting ACE2, highlighting its potential significance in overseeing gene expression associated with immune and inflammatory responses.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: The findings associated with rs4646131 suggested its role within the ACE2 regulatory framework and possible connections to inflammatory markers, given the context of ACE2 regulation by SARS-CoV infections.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: The SNP rs1023574 was identified across all three cattle breeds (RAN, SIM, GEL) as part of a common local adaptation signature on chromosome 23. It had significant q-values of 1.24×10−13, 3.15×10−12, and 4.82×10−5, associating it with membership in ecoregions, specifically indicating its connection to environmental adaptations.
title: Powerful detection of polygenic selection and environmental adaptation in US beef cattle populations

finding: The SNP rs6652009 was specifically mentioned in the context of evaluating maternal and paternal chromosome contributions in the embryos. It aided in confirming edits at the EYS locus and demonstrated successful usage of linked SNPs for tracking genetic modifications at the embryonic stage.
title: Reading frame restoration at the EYS locus, and allele-specific chromosome removal after Cas9 cleavage in human embryos

finding: The variant rs181603331 was identified as a significant eQTL for the ACE2 gene, located approximately 20kb downstream of the transcription start site. This rare variant, with an allele frequency of 1%, was associated with a large decrease in ACE2 expression (log2(AFC) = -1.6), indicating a critical role in regulating gene expression linked to COVID-19 susceptibility.
title: Type 2 and interferon inflammation strongly regulate SARS-CoV-2 related gene expression in the airway epithelium

finding: The SNP rs12010028 was linked to differences in sensitivity to BRAF inhibition, specifically in colorectal cancer. The findings indicated that this SNP could correlate significantly with experimental sensitivities observed in cell lines, contributing to a better understanding of individual responses based on genetic makeup.
title: Personalized logical models to investigate cancer response to BRAF treatments in melanomas and colorectal cancers

finding: The archaic allele (A) of the rs111811311 polymorphism (A/G) of the TKTL1 gene was investigated among carriers in the UK Biobank. It was noted to cause a missense change that was previously linked to significant effects on neurogenesis. However, assessment of carriers revealed no differences in relevant anatomical brain measures, and many carriers had college/university degrees. This finding challenged earlier claims regarding the importance of this variant in human/Neandertal brain differences, emphasizing the necessity to analyze individual sites comprehensively.
title: Evaluating the effects of archaic protein-altering variants in living human adults

finding: The SNP rs1204041 was identified as a significant association for male pattern baldness in the African cohort, being specific to Africa with allele frequency differences observed—0.488 in Africa versus negligible frequencies in Europe and East Asia. This suggests rs1204041's relevance to baldness in African men, marking it as an original finding.
title: Uncovering the genetic architecture and evolutionary roots of androgenetic alopecia in African men

finding: The ACE2 D355N variant [rs961360700] restricted the spike protein-ACE2 interaction and limited SARS-CoV-2 infection both in vitro and in vivo. This variant demonstrated reduced susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 and could modulate human susceptibility to the virus, suggesting its role in variability of disease severity among individuals.
title: Susceptibilities of human ACE2 genetic variants in coronavirus infection

finding: The non-synonymous variant rs41300872 (p.Gly197Arg) was found to have a significant association with male infertility, presenting an odds ratio of 1.77 and a p-value of 0.002. This variant was identified through whole gene sequencing in a large cohort of infertile men, suggesting its role in male germ cell dysfunction related to infertility.
title: TEX13B is important for germ cell development and male fertility

finding: The rare variant rs775429506 (p.Gly237Glu) was exclusively identified in two men diagnosed with non-obstructive azoospermia (NOA). This finding indicates a potential association with male infertility in cases of severe spermatogenic failure.
title: TEX13B is important for germ cell development and male fertility

finding: The SNP rs34729789 was identified in a male infant who exhibited microcephaly, seizures, polycystic kidney disease, and end-stage renal failure. Whole exome sequencing revealed a significant hemizygous, X-linked G>A variant in EFHC2. Although the exact function of EFHC2 was not well characterized, it and its paralog EFHC1 were thought to encode proteins involved in motile cilia. The connection of this SNP to polycystic kidney disease was unexpected due to the absence of motile cilia in mammalian kidneys.
title: Ancient eukaryotic protein interactions illuminate modern genetic traits and disorders

finding: In the PC-3 prostate cancer cell line, the risk 'A' allele of rs5945572 showed significantly decreased transcriptional activity compared to the normal 'G' allele, indicating a negative regulatory effect.
title: A dinucleotide tag-based parallel reporter gene assay method

finding: The risk allele of rs1327301 in LNCaP cells demonstrated significantly lower transcriptional activity compared to the normal allele, suggesting it negatively affects gene regulation.
title: A dinucleotide tag-based parallel reporter gene assay method

finding: The SNP rs12688220 with the TT variant was identified as a significant risk factor for chronic pancreatitis in North American patients of European ancestry. The homozygous (or hemizygous male) CLDN2 genotype associated with this variant carried the greatest risk, especially when amplified by alcohol consumption, indicating the potential role of this locus in pancreatitis susceptibility.
title: Claudin-2 limits pancreatitis development through regulating tight junction-controlled pancreatic ductal transport

finding: The SNP rs3088074, located in the ATRX gene, was frequently observed in the hiPSC lines analyzed, confirming its role in validating clonal and monoallelic expression of ATRX in all samples except for F002. This finding provided evidence of the maintenance of monoallelic expression of ATRX despite varying XCI status, highlighting its significance in understanding X-linked gene regulation.
title: Erosion of X-Chromosome Inactivation in female hiPSCs is heterogeneous and persists during differentiation

finding: The rs73635825 (S19P) allele of the hACE2 receptor was associated with some level of resistance or protection against SARS-CoV-2 infection due to its low affinity to the virus receptor binding domain (RBD). This finding indicated that variations in the ACE2 receptor might have important implications for susceptibility to infection.
title: A computational approach to evaluate the combined effect of SARS-CoV-2 RBD mutations and ACE2 receptor genetic variants on infectivity: The COVID-19 host-pathogen nexus

finding: The rs143936283 (E329G) allele of the hACE2 receptor demonstrated a similar potential for resistance against SARS-CoV-2 by exhibiting a low binding affinity to the virus's RBD. This suggests that this genetic variant could influence an individual's susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: A computational approach to evaluate the combined effect of SARS-CoV-2 RBD mutations and ACE2 receptor genetic variants on infectivity: The COVID-19 host-pathogen nexus

finding: The study identified a significant correlation between the oxytocin receptor (OXTR) and the fucosylation process regulated by B3GNT7, with the specific SNP rs11091241 being linked to fucose linkages in cancer as reported in the literature. The OXTR depletion was associated with increased susceptibility to colitis and colitis-associated colorectal cancer (CAC), suggesting that variations in rs11091241 could influence cancer development through effects on oxytocin signaling and MUC2 maturation in the colon.
title: Oxytocin alleviated colitis and colitis-associated colorectal tumorigenesis by targeting fucosylated MUC2

finding: The SNP rs3853839 in the TLR7 gene was found to influence COVID-19 susceptibility, severity, and clinical outcomes in middle-aged individuals without previous comorbidities. This finding indicated that variations in TLR7 mRNA expression driven by this polymorphism could play a significant role in the host response to SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: The SARS-CoV-2 Spike S1 Protein Induces Global Proteomic Changes in ATII-Like Rat L2 Cells that are Attenuated by Hyaluronan

finding: The SNP rs392020 was assigned to the gene SLC25A5, based on its status as an exonic nonsynonymous variant. This prioritization was part of a broader analysis of loci associated with mtDNA-CN, emphasizing the importance of this SNP in the context of ATP transport and mitochondrial function.
title: Genetic analysis of mitochondrial DNA copy number and associated traits identifies loci implicated in nucleotide metabolism, platelet activation, and megakaryocyte proliferation, and reveals a causal association of mitochondrial function with mortality

finding: For rs1050828, which encodes the G6PD+202T allele, the results indicated that this SNP was associated with protection from severe malaria in the 'severe malaria' sub-population with an odds ratio of 0.71 (95% C.I. 0.57-0.88). In contrast, it was associated with increased risk in the 'not severe malaria' sub-population with an odds ratio of 1.30 (95% C.I. 1.00-1.70). This opposing effect suggested that G6PD deficiency might lead to erroneous classification as severe malaria due to the severe anaemia criterion.
title: Improving statistical power in severe malaria genetic association studies by augmenting phenotypic precision

finding: This G6PD deficiency variant was strongly associated with total and direct bilirubin levels, indicating its role in bilirubin metabolism and the risk of neonatal jaundice in G6PD-deficient individuals.
title: Analyses of Biomarker Traits in Diverse UK Biobank Participants Identify Associations Missed by European-centric Analysis Strategies

finding: The G6PD Mediterranean variant rs5030868 was associated with HbA1c levels in South Asian participants, suggesting a significant impact of this variant on glycemic control, particularly in populations with a high prevalence of G6PD deficiency.
title: Analyses of Biomarker Traits in Diverse UK Biobank Participants Identify Associations Missed by European-centric Analysis Strategies

finding: The rs4646116 SNP, predicted to encode the p.Lys26Arg allele, exhibited a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 1.43% in Ashkenazi Jewish males, with a higher observed rate in females at 2.16%. This allele represented a common missense ACE2 variant that may affect binding to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein, notable in epidemiological studies linking host genetic factors to COVID-19 progression.
title: ACE 2 Coding Variants: A Potential X-linked Risk Factor for COVID-19 Disease

finding: The rs41303171 SNP, encoding the p.Asn720Asp variant, was found in 1.7% of male gnomAD samples and 3.1%-3.2% in females. Although frequent enough to be considered in genome-wide association studies, it was noted that this allele does not lie in a predicted functional site for SARS-CoV-2 interaction, making it a less obvious candidate for affecting COVID-19 severity directly.
title: ACE 2 Coding Variants: A Potential X-linked Risk Factor for COVID-19 Disease

finding: The rs763395248 SNP, encoding the p.Thr92Ile variant, was detected in Southern European males at a very low frequency (2 out of 7040 X chromosomes, equivalent to MAF of 0.00028). Preliminary in vitro studies suggested that this variant could enhance the binding of SARS-CoV-2 to ACE2, thus highlighting its potential role in the dynamics of infection and warranting further functional assays.
title: ACE 2 Coding Variants: A Potential X-linked Risk Factor for COVID-19 Disease

finding: The SNP rs12010146 was positively associated with neurocognitive decline following cranial irradiation. It was specifically linked to mechanisms involved in cognitive dysfunction, which was observed in mice exposed to irradiation. The study suggested a potential role of this SNP in the regulation of the cognitive impairment associated with radiation therapy, thereby highlighting its significance in neurocognitive outcomes in patients receiving such treatment.
title: PAK3 downregulation induces cognitive impairment following cranial irradiation

finding: The SNP rs11091216 was associated with the Wnt signaling pathway in relation to keratinocyte carcinomas. In the context of actinic keratosis (AK) progression to cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC), it had been indicated that disruptions in the Wnt signaling pathway may contribute to the development and malignancy of skin lesions.
title: Topical GZ21T inhibits the growth of actinic keratoses in a UVB induced model of skin carcinogenesis

finding: The SNP rs5919432, located 71kb from the androgen receptor gene at Xq12, was originally discovered in European men as associated with prostate cancer (CaP). In the MADCaP study, it showed a higher frequency of the risk-increasing T allele in cases (34.2%) compared to controls (32.1%) in African populations, indicating a similar effect in these groups.
title: A custom genotyping array reveals population-level heterogeneity for the genetic risks of prostate cancer and other cancers in Africa

finding: The M1V variant (rs3764880) of the TLR8 gene was associated with enhanced intracellular killing of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) in primary macrophages from individuals homozygous or hemizygous for the variant. This variant led to an increase in phagosomal acidification and greater inflammatory cytokine release when compared to wild type controls. It was implicated in protection against pulmonary tuberculosis in various population genetic studies and was found to be more frequent in Far Eastern populations.
title: Phagosomal RNA sensing through TLR8 controls susceptibility to tuberculosis

finding: SNP rs2681646 was associated with variance of waist circumference at X-chromosome-wide significance in the UK Biobank (p=9.5E-07), with a suggestive female-specific effect observed in the MESA dataset (p=0.048). This finding highlights its relevance to phenotypic variance in waist circumference.
title: Analytical strategies to include the X-chromosome in variance heterogeneity analyses: evidence for trait-specific polygenic variance structure

finding: This SNP caused the K26R missense variant in the ACE2 gene, associated with activated receptor functionality that increased the binding affinity for the SARS-CoV-2 S-protein. This variant was common in Europeans but rare in East Asians and Africans, detected in Kuwaiti population with a MAF of 0.29%.
title: A comprehensive germline variant and expression analyses of ACE2, TMPRSS2 and SARS-CoV-2 activator FURIN genes from the Middle East: Combating SARS-CoV-2 with precision medicine

finding: This SNP resulted in the N720D missense variant in the ACE2 gene. It was the most prevalent variant in Europeans and suggested to enhance TMPRSS2 activity, which facilitates viral entry. Its prevalence was relatively lower in Middle Eastern populations.
title: A comprehensive germline variant and expression analyses of ACE2, TMPRSS2 and SARS-CoV-2 activator FURIN genes from the Middle East: Combating SARS-CoV-2 with precision medicine

finding: Previously identified variant rs7889328 was associated with red blood cell (RBC) traits, specifically remaining significant after controlling for known GWAS variants at the locus. The variant created a transcription factor binding site (TFBS) for CTCFL in the promoter of the gene RENBP. This association was notable in individuals of African and Hispanic ethnicity and demonstrated a relationship with RBC indices including RBC count, RBC distribution width, and mean corpuscular volume. The study found that alleles at rs7889328 accounted for the remaining association signal after considering existing GWAS data.
title: find-tfbs: a tool to identify functional non-coding variants associated with complex human traits using open chromatin maps and phased whole-genome sequences

finding: The SNP rs311071 was mapped 66.3 kb and 0.0007 cM distal to the PAB, reinforcing the original findings about the position of the pseudoautosomal region.
title: Where is the boundary of the human pseudoautosomal region?

finding: The SNP rs5982851 was reported to be only 246 bases distal to the Alu insertion that marks the PAB, and its finding contributed to narrowing the PAB location, aligning with historical recombination events observed.
title: Where is the boundary of the human pseudoautosomal region?

finding: The GABRA3 gene SNP rs1112122 showed an approaching significant association (p=0.099), where subjects with normal expression were five times more likely (OR=4.746) to be categorized as responders to c-tDCS, compared to those with variant expression, who were less likely (OR=0.211).
title: Genetic polymorphisms do not predict inter-individual variability to cathodal transcranial direct current stimulation of the primary motor cortex

finding: The rs1322436793 (G305R) mutation was identified as damaging due to its impact on residue size and charge, resulting in potential bumps and repulsion of ligands. The mutation disrupted local protein structure.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs1064794027 (C182Y) mutation was characterized as damaging because the larger mutant residue could not fit within the hydrophobic core of the IL2RG protein, leading to a loss of critical hydrophobic interactions.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs111033620 (G114D) mutation was found to be damaging, as the mutated residue caused incorrect backbone conformation and disturbed local protein structure due to its size and torsion angle.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs193922347 (Y105C) mutation was predicted to be damaging due to the smaller mutant residue potentially resulting in a loss of external interactions, affecting the protein's binding sites.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs1293196743 (Y91C) mutation was identified as damaging because the smaller mutant residue created an empty space in the hydrophobic core of the protein, negatively impacting its function.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs1057517950 (W240R) mutation was previously identified as damaging in a patient with X-SCID, corroborating the findings of the current study.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs869320659 (R226C) mutation was attributed to a genetic mosaicism responsible for X-SCID, aligning with findings in other studies.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs869320658 (R224W) mutation was recognized as damaging, consistent with retrospective analysis of related studies.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs111033618 (R222C) mutation was noted for causing an atypical SCID phenotype, as previously documented, affirming its association with the disease.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs137852511 (L151P) mutation was identified in a patient, revealing a reversion in T cells leading to a restored immune function, thus categorizing it as damaging.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs111033622 (C115R) mutation was recognized in a patient displaying an atypical X-SCID phenotype, linked to a functional reversion in lymphocyte precursors.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs1057520293 (L87P) mutation was described in an X-SCID patient with mild symptoms indicating its damaging potential.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The variant rs6318 had an extremely high MAF of 98.5% in HKG, which was associated with an increased likelihood of drug-related weight gain based on three different studies. This suggests its importance in pharmacogenetics related to weight management in this population.
title: HKG: An open genetic variant database of 205 Hong Kong Cantonese exomes
