finding: The SNP rs1460413167 (P212H) led to a missense mutation where Proline changed to Histidine at position 212. It was identified as one of the most deleterious mutations impacting the GPC3 protein structure and function, contributing to the molecular basis of Simpson-Golabi-Behmel Syndrome.
title: Identification of novel key biomarkers in Simpson-Golabi-Behmel Syndrome: Evidence from bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP rs1295603457 (C65Y) resulted in a missense mutation wherein Cysteine was altered to Tyrosine at position 65. This mutation was noted for its significant deleterious effects on GPC3 structure and function, highlighting its relevance to overgrowth syndrome.
title: Identification of novel key biomarkers in Simpson-Golabi-Behmel Syndrome: Evidence from bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP rs757475450 (R39C) caused a missense mutation that changed Arginine to Cysteine at position 39. This mutation was assessed as highly detrimental to the GPC3 protein, reinforcing its association with the Simpson-Golabi-Behmel Syndrome.
title: Identification of novel key biomarkers in Simpson-Golabi-Behmel Syndrome: Evidence from bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP rs6323 was previously examined in relation to the MAOA gene, associating it with anger-driven aggression. The study's findings highlighted the link between functional polymorphisms in the MAOA gene and the heritability of aggressive behaviors, suggesting that this specific SNP may contribute to the propensity for aggressive antisocial and violent behavior.
title: Identification of Six novel missense single nucleotide polymorphisms in the MAOA gene predisposing to aggressive behavior. Bioinformatics study

finding: The SNP rs12010254 was linked to the expression of MYBBP1A, which contributes to metabolism plasticity and stemness within the tumor microenvironment. This finding highlights the relevance of metabolism-related genes in AML prognosis, particularly in the context of poor outcome KMT2A rearranged leukaemia, as discussed in its interactions with the biological characteristics of AML subtypes.
title: Integrative phosphoproteomics defines two biologically distinct groups of KMT2A rearranged acute myeloid leukaemia with different drug response phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs1137070, located in the MAOA gene, was found to interactively alter the gray matter volume of the salience network in individuals with heroin addiction. This finding was based on data collected by Sun et al. (2017), which highlighted the relationship between this genetic variation and the structural brain changes associated with addiction.
title: The anterior insular cortex in the rat exerts an inhibitory influence over the loss of control of heroin intake and subsequent propensity to relapse

finding: The analysis of rs2041952 indicated that it was associated with the regulation of caspases in cancer biology. This SNP was highlighted in the context of a study suggesting that caspase-independent mechanisms, including the role of FN and autophagy, were crucial for cell survival in various conditions, specifically in Casp3-deficient settings. Thus, it contributed to understanding the enigmatic roles of caspases and their interaction with cellular pathways implicated in tumor development.
title: Caspase3-deficient cells require fibronectin for protection against autophagy-dependent death

finding: The SNP rs12010226 was associated with the study published by Casciati et al. in 2020, which investigated cancer stem cell-like phenotypes in human medulloblastoma cell lines. The finding indicated a link between this SNP and specific biological characteristics of these tumors, contributing to understanding their heterogeneous nature.
title: Modulation of Viability, Proliferation, and Stemness by Rosmarinic Acid in Medulloblastoma Cells: Involvement of HDACs and EGFR

finding: The SNP rs12010130 was associated with enhanced anti-tumor efficacy in the context of gammadelta T cell therapy. Specifically, it was found that IL-2/IL-12/18-stimulated gammadelta T cells, relevant to this SNP, demonstrated potent anti-tumoral function through mechanisms such as direct killing of tumor cells and induction of senescence in those cells, signaling a significant role in cancer immunotherapy.
title: IL-12/18/21 pre-activation enhances the anti-tumor efficacy of expanded γδT cells and overcomes resistance to anti-PD-L1 treatment

finding: Located in the RGN gene, this missense variant was found to be associated with gluconate levels, underscoring its involvement in metabolic pathways.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: Associated with guanidino and acetamido levels, this SNP also showed novel associations with branched-chain amino acids and various metabolism pathways, signifying its broad metabolic impact.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: This variant in the VSIG4 gene demonstrated a significant association with long chain monounsaturated fatty acids, suggesting its regulatory role in lipid metabolism.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: Associated with guaiacol sulfate through the ASMTL gene, this SNP further contributes to our understanding of metabolic regulation.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: The SNP rs12010078 was associated with the characterization of the JAK1 pseudokinase domain, influencing cytokine signaling pathways. This finding highlighted its relevance in the context of hyperproteinemia and blood cell homeostasis.
title: Mechanism of hyperproteinemia-induced blood cell homeostasis imbalance in an animal model

finding: The SNP rs2071223 was associated with Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) in male lymphocytes, showing a significant association with a p-value of 0.005. This finding indicated a potential male-specific role of BTK in the severity of COVID-19, underscoring the importance of genetic factors in understanding sex differences related to disease outcomes.
title: Multimodal Single-Cell Omics Analysis of COVID-19 Sex Differences in Human Immune Systems

finding: The SNP rs12010002 was associated with metabolic alterations in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) progression as noted in the study by Vernucci et al. (2019). This study emphasized metabolic reprogramming in PDAC cells, which was indicated by significant findings related to the peroxisomal fatty acid beta oxidation pathway and reactive oxygen species detoxification pathways.
title: Exploring the metabolic landscape of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma cells using genome-scale metabolic modeling

finding: The SNP rs190509934 was associated with COVID-19 infection risk due to its effect on ACE2 expression levels. RegulomeDB identified multiple hits to DNase-seq peaks in lung-related biosamples, supporting the hypothesis that ACE2 expression may be regulated by CEBP, as evidenced by overlaps with DNase footprints in the upstream promoter region of ACE2.
title: Annotating and prioritizing human non-coding variants with RegulomeDB

finding: The SNP rs4898 in the TIMP1 gene was associated with early-onset preeclampsia development, which is a significant condition affecting pregnancy. The study noted that this polymorphism also had an impact on placenta weight, suggesting that it may influence placental health and function during pregnancy. This finding contributed to a better understanding of genetic factors involved in reproductive diseases.
title: Single-cell transcriptomic analysis of immune cell dynamics in the healthy human endometrium

finding: The analysis indicated that rs12010210 was associated with the therapeutic potential of metformin as a treatment for high-grade glioma, suggesting a genetic predisposition to respond positively to metformin therapy.
title: A combination of Metformin and Epigallocatechin Gallate Potentiates Glioma Chemotherapy in vivo

finding: The rs6152 variant was linked to prostate cancer susceptibility, being located within the AR gene and interacting with an enhancer that regulates AR expression.
title: Exploring the effects of genetic variation on gene regulation in cancer in the context of 3D genome structure

finding: The SNP rs201194898 located in the NPR showed genome-wide significant sdMAF p-values, indicating that minor allele frequencies were significantly larger in females than in males across all five super-populations. The sdMAF p-values were less than 1e-200, confirming a strong female bias.
title: Major sex differences in allele frequencies for X chromosome variants in the 1000 Genomes Project data

finding: Similar to rs201194898, the SNP rs6634333 in the NPR also displayed significant sdMAF, with female allele frequencies being notably higher than male frequencies across five super-populations. Significant HWE testing results were observed in females, indicating an excess of heterozygous females in all populations except SAS.
title: Major sex differences in allele frequencies for X chromosome variants in the 1000 Genomes Project data

finding: At position X:21940733A/G, the SNP rs34507903 was identified in the gene coding for spermine synthase (SMS) in four female placentas. The findings indicated that this gene exhibited biallelic expression, which was linked to X chromosome inactivation escape in the context of altered polyamine metabolism and its association with placental dysfunction and pregnancy disorders.
title: Placental polyamines regulate acetyl-coA and histone acetylation in a sex-specific manner

finding: At position X:48894188G/A, the SNP rs1128363 was identified in the X-linked gene TIMM17B. This gene was chosen as a control due to its stable expression levels that did not significantly change by sex. The findings contributed to understanding the background of X-linked gene expression in relation to sex differences observed in placental gene regulation.
title: Placental polyamines regulate acetyl-coA and histone acetylation in a sex-specific manner

finding: SNP rs142932029 in the gene FTSJ1 showed a highly significant association with facial morphology, with a p-value of 1.59 × 10−14. This variant was part of a study indicating large effects of low-frequency variants on facial traits.
title: Impact of low-frequency coding variants on human facial shape

finding: The finding for SNP rs12010131 indicated its role in influencing cell viability, suggesting that TRPM7 could be targeted to suppress the breast cancer cell cycle.
title: Pan-Cancer Genetic Profiles of Mitotic DNA Integrity Checkpoint Protein Kinases

finding: The SNP rs11091354 was linked to purine metabolism and apoptosis within cancer cells as described in the referenced study by Camici et al. (2019). It portrayed a significant association with metabolic processes that can impact cancer growth, particularly in terms of nucleotide biosynthesis and its relation to cellular apoptosis.
title: L-glyceraldehyde inhibits neuroblastoma cell growth via a multi-modal mechanism on metabolism and signaling

finding: The study reported that the rs952836 SNP was identified within the interval shared by all affected individuals from families FALS5 and FALS14. This interval, associated with the UBQLN2 gene, confirmed a founder effect of the UBQLN2 p.T487I mutation, which was linked to ALS and/or FTD phenotypes in these families.
title: Hippocampal protein aggregation signatures fully distinguish pathogenic and wildtype UBQLN2 in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

finding: Similar to rs952836, the rs6423133 SNP was part of the identified 68 cM interval shared among affected individuals from families FALS5 and FALS14. This finding also supported the pathogenicity of the UBQLN2 p.T487I mutation, indicating its role in the ALS/FTD spectrum.
title: Hippocampal protein aggregation signatures fully distinguish pathogenic and wildtype UBQLN2 in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

finding: The R625X (p.Arg625Ter) mutation in the CACNA1F gene was found to cause a premature stop codon, leading to loss of normal protein function, and was linked to primary immunodeficiency, X-linked incomplete congenital stationary night blindness, and immune dysfunction in the studied siblings. This mutation was previously documented in a family with similar symptoms.
title: Mutation of an L-Type Calcium Channel Gene Leads to a Novel Human Primary Cellular Immunodeficiency

finding: There was a significant finding related to the SNP rs12010041, which was associated with integrin α6β4 expression in colorectal cancer (CRC). The article referenced indicated that this SNP could have implications in understanding alterations in expression patterns and functional roles of integrins, particularly in relation to the tumor microenvironment. This finding provided insights into potential biomarkers for cancer management.
title: Unveiling the Mechanisms to Bypass KRAS Inhibition: In Vitro Insights into the Influence of Fibroblast-Secretome

finding: The SNP rs12092652 was associated with putative driver alterations in cancer samples. The research highlighted that a subset of tumor cells exhibited an enrichment of these alterations compared to normal cells, suggesting that this SNP may play a role in cancer cell identification and analysis.
title: A novel computational approach to identify cancer cells in scRNA-seq data

finding: At the rs56269549 locus, located on the X chromosome, targeted DAF-seq was employed to phase bottom strand reads in GM12878 cells. This study revealed that the four UBA1 transcriptional start sites (TSSs) displayed distinct accessibility patterns based on haplotype variations, confirming the method's aptitude for analyzing single heterozygous variants in chromatin contexts. The canonical UBA1 TSS was accessible on both the Xa and Xi alleles, while three upstream TSSs were selectively accessible on the Xa haplotype, indicating a clear relationship between genetic architecture and gene regulation.
title: Deaminase-assisted single-molecule and single-cell chromatin fiber sequencing

finding: The SNP rs112977454 was identified as an expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) with a notable segregation in African populations. This variant was found to have a CADD score of 9.018, indicating a potential for pathogenicity, and it significantly impacted the transcription factor binding to the gene JPX, which is involved in X chromosome inactivation. The region associated with this SNP presented a strong signal of positive selection in African populations, reflecting modifications in the regulatory activity of enhancers linked to the transcription regulation of JPX and potentially contributing to population-specific adaptations.
title: Chromosome X-wide analysis of positive selection in human populations: from common and private signals to selection impact on inactivated genes and enhancers-like signatures

finding: The SNP rs5913773 was identified as replicating in a previous study related to Red Blood Cell (RBC) traits. Among 7 findings for RBC, 5 were novel while 2, including rs5913773, were previously reported.
title: Light-speed whole genome association testing and prediction via Approximate Message Passing

finding: The SNP rs5960376 also replicated in a previous study concerning Red Blood Cell (RBC) traits, sharing the same novelty status as rs5913773.
title: Light-speed whole genome association testing and prediction via Approximate Message Passing

finding: The SNP rs1339116 was described as novel and was located intragenically near the DIAPH2 gene, which is associated with High-Density Lipoprotein (HDL) levels.
title: Light-speed whole genome association testing and prediction via Approximate Message Passing

finding: The SNP rs10126777 was noted to be near the TBX22 gene, which was linked to bone formation and cleft palate, being one of the 21 novel findings for Bone Mineral Density (BMD) traits.
title: Light-speed whole genome association testing and prediction via Approximate Message Passing

finding: The SNP rs189438396 was found to be upstream of the PTCHD1 gene with a p-value of 0.0019, contributing to the 41 novel findings associated with Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH) traits.
title: Light-speed whole genome association testing and prediction via Approximate Message Passing

finding: The ITM2A rs1751094 polymorphism was reported to be associated with autoimmune thyroid disease in Korean pediatric patients, according to Cho et al. in 2023.
title: Identification of differentially expressed genes and enriched pathways in inflammatory bowel disease using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: This SNP, positioned approximately 2 kb upstream of the TSS of XPNPEP2, was highlighted in SuRE assays for demonstrating a strong (approximately 5-fold) concordant effect on enhancer activity in HepG2 cells.
title: Systematic identification of human SNPs affecting regulatory element activity

finding: The SNP variant rs2269372, located on chromosome X at position 153,207,545, was associated with schizophrenia in a Han Chinese population and systemic lupus erythematosus in a European population, both at a genome-wide significance level of P < 5×10^-8. This finding related to the gene RENBP, which was implicated in the age-by-sex interaction study.
title: An epigenome-wide association study of sex-specific chronological ageing

finding: The SNP rs12010052 was identified as a significant marker related to the expression of circulating extracellular vesicle microRNA, which served as a diagnostic biomarker in early colorectal cancer. This finding underscored the potential of using microRNA profiles in extracellular vesicles for early detection and prognosis of this cancer type.
title: In situ investigation of extracellular vesicles in viscous formulations: interplay of nanoparticle transport and nano rheology through interferometric light microscopy analysis

finding: The study noted that the XEDAR coding variant R57K (rs1385699) was suggested to be a target of positive natural selection in East Asia. This finding highlighted the evolutionary significance of this variant and its potential impact on ectodermal appendage development, particularly in relation to mammary gland differentiation.
title: Ectodysplasin signaling via Xedar is required for mammary gland morphogenesis

finding: The finding related to the SNP rs4646116 (p.Lys26Arg) indicated that this variant was predominant in the Ashkenazi Jewish and European non-Finnish cohorts, with an allele frequency of 0.01 and 0.006 respectively. It was discovered that this variant enhanced the binding affinity for the SARS-CoV-2 Spike protein, indicating a potential increased susceptibility to infection or severe disease caused by COVID-19. This connection underscored its relevance in the global epidemiology of COVID-19.
title: Missense variants in human ACE2 modify binding to SARS-CoV-2 Spike

finding: The variant rs139643362 was identified as a pathogenic variant linked to X-linked hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy. This finding specifically pointed to oligodendrocytes as the relevant brain cell type. This was further supported by searches in the mouse brain atlas, which showed matches for glia and Schwann cells in the dorsal root ganglion, aligning with literature that implicated this disease in myelination deficiencies.
title: Fast searches of large collections of single cell data using scfind

finding: The study identified the G6PD Mediterranean mutation, rs5030868 (G>A; p.S188F), associated with malaria resistance. This mutation was found in three out of four ancient Bahraini samples, particularly in the individuals AS_EMT (homozygous) and MH2_LT (heterozygous). The presence of the mutation suggested that it had increased in frequency in Eastern Arabia from around 5-6 thousand years ago, correlating with the emergence of agriculture in the region. Additionally, this mutation was confirmed in a phylogenetic analysis where ancient Bahraini samples clustered with current populations from the Arabian Peninsula, but was absent in other ancient populations from Lebanon and Greece.
title: Ancient genomes illuminate Eastern Arabian population history and adaptation against malaria

finding: The SNP rs5945430 was associated with a severe clinical course in male patients with Multiple Sclerosis. While this finding primarily relates to Multiple Sclerosis, it raises the potential for shared genetic factors that could influence other metabolic and neurological conditions, including obesity-related diabetes.
title: Bioinformatics Analysis of Key Genes and Pathways for Obesity Associated Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus as a Therapeutic Target

finding: The SNP rs11091285 was associated with K(Ca)3.1 channels, which were found to confer radioresistance to breast cancer cells. This finding suggested that variations at this locus may influence how breast cancer cells respond to radiation therapy.
title: Monitoring extracellular ion and metabolite dynamics with recombinant nanobody-fused biosensors

finding: The variant rs878853698 was located at the interface of the GLA-GLA complex and was connected to Fabry disease. This mutation resulted in a damaging effect on the enzymatic activity of the lysosomal enzyme alpha-galactosidase A, leading to the clinical manifestations of Fabry's disease such as cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis. Similar to the previous case, this variant was marked as "likely pathogenic" by ClinVar and was predicted by SWING to be disruptive of its corresponding protein-protein interaction, while it was missed by AlphaMissense.
title: Sliding Window INteraction Grammar (SWING): a generalized interaction language model for peptide and protein interactions

finding: SNP rs11094813 was used as a proxy for the missing SNP rs12556975 in the female cerebellum FUSION eQTL panel, demonstrating high imputation quality metrics with r^2 values above 0.9.
title: Analysis of expression Quantitative Trait Loci for NLGN4X in relation to language and neurodevelopmental function: an exploratory analysis using FUSION and GTEx workflows

finding: SNP rs150758913 was included in the analyses as a proxy for rs182391645 after confirming concordance in monozygotic twins, though it had a lower quality metric (R-squared of 0.54) in terms of imputation quality.
title: Analysis of expression Quantitative Trait Loci for NLGN4X in relation to language and neurodevelopmental function: an exploratory analysis using FUSION and GTEx workflows

finding: The SNP rs11091137 was found to be significantly associated with the perceived diversity of forests as indicated in prior research. The study by Frey et al. (2019) explored the relationship between forest structural complexity and various biodiversity factors including tree species richness, suggesting that genetic variations such as those indicated by rs11091137 could influence individual perceptions of biodiversity and its impact on mental well-being.
title: Perceived biodiversity: is what we measure also what we see and hear?

finding: The SNP rs2239464, located in the methyl-CpG binding protein 2 (MeCP2) gene on the X chromosome, was associated with reduced cortical surface area specifically in males. This finding was established through analysis in two independent datasets, emphasizing a sex-based difference in its impact; the effect was not observed in females, which was hypothesized to be due to females possessing a second copy of the gene that provides protective effects.
title: Sex differences in Variability of Brain Structure Across the Lifespan

finding: The SNP rs11091220 related to the p21 (Cip1/Waf1/CDKN1A) gene, which plays a critical role in cell cycle regulation. The findings illustrated its association with the modulation of cell proliferation and transition from G1 to S phase in cancer contexts, including bladder cancer.
title: Benzidine Induces Proliferation of UMUC3 Bladder Cancer Cells Through Activation of ERK5 Pathway

finding: The common variant rs1050828-T in the G6PD gene, identified as p.Val98Met, was strongly associated with decreased HbA1c in both African-Americans and Hispanics, with a P-value of 5.1 × 10^-210. It accounted for 23% of HbA1c variance in African-Americans and 4% in Hispanics. This variant likely resulted in erythrocytic lifespan shortening due to G6PD deficiency, impacting the HbA1c levels measured.
title: Impact of rare and common genetic variants on diabetes diagnosis by hemoglobin A1c in multi-ancestry cohorts: The Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine Program

finding: The rare variant rs76723693-G in G6PD was also significantly associated with HbA1c, showing a decrease in HbA1c of -0.98% in hemizygous males and -0.46% in heterozygous females. It had a P-value of 2.8 × 10^-15 and is characterized as affecting erythrocytic traits, similar to the more common rs1050828. It was identified to account for additional variance in HbA1c when considered alongside rs1050828.
title: Impact of rare and common genetic variants on diabetes diagnosis by hemoglobin A1c in multi-ancestry cohorts: The Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine Program

finding: The G>C substitution (SNP rs138166791) was located in the penultimate position of the 3p passenger strand of hsa-miR-890. This mutation significantly lowered the cleavage efficiency by DROSHA and consequently decreased the levels of both mature miR-890-5p and passenger miR-890-3p, indicating a direct impact on miRNA processing associated with alterations in gene regulation.
title: Pan-Cancer analysis of somatic mutations in miRNA genes

finding: The SNP rs6609533 in TIMP-1 was associated with susceptibility to Type 2 diabetes, suggesting a role in the regulation of metalloproteinase activity in diabetes.
title: Identification of Key Genes and Underlying Mechanisms in Cystic Fibrosis and its Associated Complications Based on Bioinformatics Analysis of Next Generation Sequencing Data Analysis

finding: The variant rs6152 was mentioned concerning its association with an increased risk of baldness, particularly relevant for males looking to ascertain their predisposition to early-onset hair loss.
title: Towards a new standard in genomic data privacy: a realization of owner-governance

finding: The study reported a significant association between the GABRA3 gene SNP rs4828696 and the categorization of individuals as responders or non-responders to a-tDCS. Those with the 'variant expression' of this SNP were found to be 3.5 times more likely to be categorized as responders compared to those with 'normal expression'. Additionally, significant increases in corticospinal excitability (CSE) were noted for the 'variant expression' subgroup following a-tDCS, indicating a relationship between GABA-A receptor variations and the capacity to undergo cortical plasticity.
title: Can genetic polymorphisms predict response variability to anodal transcranial direct current stimulation of the primary motor cortex?

finding: The study found a significant association between the GABRA3 gene SNP rs1112122 and responder/non-responder subgroup categorization, indicating those with 'variant expression' were three times more likely to be responders compared to the 'normal expression' group, showcasing its relevance in predicting a-tDCS response.
title: Can genetic polymorphisms predict response variability to anodal transcranial direct current stimulation of the primary motor cortex?

finding: The variant rs1059702 was reported to be associated with hematological traits, as indicated in the study results, which also achieved a VDA score of 0.7.
title: Comprehensive assessment of Indian variations in the druggable kinome landscape highlights distinct insights at the sequence, structure and pharmacogenomic stratum

finding: The study suggested that the MAOA rs1137070 SNP was associated with changes in gray matter volume (GMV) within the salience network of the brain among heroin addiction patients. The findings indicated that this specific SNP altered GMV in conjunction with heroin intake, linking genetic factors to structural brain changes in individuals with opioid use disorder (OUD). This highlighted the potential role of the MAOA gene variant in the neurobiological effects of heroin.
title: Long-access heroin self-administration induces region specific reduction of grey matter volume and microglia reactivity in the rat

finding: The SNP rs1718043 at the DMD locus exhibited a significant association with serum urate levels in the Japanese population (P = 8.8 x 10^-5), affirming its potential role in urate metabolism.
title: Genomic dissection of 43 serum urate-associated loci provides multiple insights into molecular mechanisms of urate control
